doc.field: Old index of Volume I of the correspondence

Index of late seventeenth century letter arrangement of volume I of the correspondence (APUG 555), containing letters of ""Popes, Kings and Princes"" to Athanasius Kircher, with later notes in pencil indicating subsequent order.
Alexander VII, Pope (Fabio Chigi), Aenigma ab Alex. VII PM solutum, MP scriptum
Various notes in the hand of Alexander VII with annotations in the hand of Athanasius Kircher
Alexander VII, Pope (Fabio Chigi) to Kircher, [Rome], undated [1665-6?]

Notes to Kircher in the hand of Alexander VII requesting information concerning a manuscript of the Sphere of Sacrobosco (BAV ms. Chigi E. IV. 130) and a collection of liturgical texts (BAV ms. Chigi C. V. 134). See Alberto Bartòla,""Alessandro VII e Athanasius Kircher S.J"", Miscellanea Bibliothecae Apostolicae Vaticanae, III (1989), 7-105
Leopold I to Kircher, Vienna, 6 August 1666
Refers to letter from Kircher, 8 July 1666. 18v = end of letter, autograph signature, followed by signature of Christophorus Abele, secretary. 19v=Imperial seal and address.
Leopoldo de' Medici to Kircher, Florence, 26 May 1665
August, Duke of Braunschweig-Lüneburg to Kircher, Wolfenbüttel, 6/16 June 1664

f. 21r: ""Das Aenigma so er hinten an seine Polygraphiam gesetzet, haben wir nach seinem bericht alsbald enodiret .. auch zween andere Exempla dabey legen wollen .. Wegen ermangelung einiger materie thun wir hiermit schliessen"". Polygraphia Universalis. 21v, 22r, 22v=exercises in cipher (pencil).
August, Duke of Braunschweig-Lüneburg to Kircher, Wolfenbüttel, 19/29 September 1664

August has received Kircher's ""angenehmes schreiben vom letzen Augusti"" and is eagerly awaiting the Mundus subterraneus: ""Gott geleite das Exemplar dass es balt moege zukommen"". He forwards with this letter ""ein aus dem hebraischen vertirtes Buch De Templo Salomonis, die in der praefation verheissene notae, wan sie zur perfection gebracht seyn, sollen von mir alsbald ihm auch zugesandt werden"". Cf. Kircher to Duke August, Rome, 31 October 1664, HAB: BA No.360. August has received Kircher's ""angenehmes schreiben vom letzen Augusti"" and is eagerly awaiting the Mundus subterraneus: ""Gott geleite das Exemplar dass es balt moege zukommen"". He forwards with this letter ""ein aus dem hebraischen vertirtes Buch De Templo Salomonis, die in der praefation verheissene notae, wan sie zur perfection gebracht seyn, sollen von mir alsbald ihm auch zugesandt werden"". Cf. Kircher to Duke August, Rome, 31 October 1664, HAB: BA No. 360.
Friedrich, Landgrave of Hesse-Darmstadt to Kircher, Heitersheim, 8 April 1665
Fisiologia Nuova della Natura delle Comete
Friedrich, Landgrave of Hesse-Darmstadt to Kircher, Heitersheim, 13 May 1665

f. 26r: ""…invio qui giunto à V. Ptà il Corso dell'ultima Cometa comparsa nell'ultimamente decorso Aprile, com'anche una Descrittione Tedesca dell'istessa, la quale darà senza dubbio, nuova materia alli curiosi ingegni d'Italia…"
Friedrich, Landgrave of Hesse-Darmstadt to Kircher, Heitersheim, 24 June 1665

f. 27r: ""Ho ricevuto quella di V. P.tà della 8 passato coll'aggiunta opretta da lei ultimamente publicata …"" Thanks Kircher for gift of Historia Eustachio-Mariana, and writes that he'll have to wait until he sees what is brought back by the flotilla of Naples before he can consider making a donation for the restoration of the shrine.
Johann Friedrich, Duke of Braunschweig-Lüneburg to Kircher, Hannover, 16 February 1668

29r=letter: ""La lunghezza del viaggio che ha dovuto far la scattola entro alla quale fui inviato un saggio della miniere d'Argento […] può forse haver portato qualche svario inordine alla quantità del Metallo"
Flavio Chigi to Kircher, Castel Gandolfo, 16 May 1665

""Hebbi il volumetto inviatomi cortesemente in dono da V. R. della Vita di S. Eustachio "" Asks Kircher to thank ""Sig. Alessandro Fabiano della Città di Los Angelos nel Messico"" for gifts. See Kircher to Flavio Chigi, 13 December 1666 (?), BAV Fondo Chigi R.V.g, 460r-v, discussing """"certa robba da nuova spagna"".
Ernst Adalbert von Harrach to Kircher, Prague, 21 November 1663
Karl Kaspar von der Leyen to Kircher, Trier, 12 October 1665
Karl Kaspar hanks Kircher for the Mundus Subterraneus.
Copia dell'instrutione data […] al S. Giulio Banfi Milanese
Filippo Carlo (Mahamet Chelebi), Prince of Tunis

36r-37r=""Copia dell'instrutione data ... al S. Giulio Banfi Milanese"" 37v=bears inscription ""Principe di Tunisi"" in ink and ""Filippo Carlo Principe di Tunis"" in pencil. 37v=bears inscription ""Principe di Tunisi"" in ink and ""Filippo Carlo Principe di Tunis"" in pencil.
Jacopo Nini to Kircher, Tunis, 11 June 1665
Letter written to accompany the ""Copia dell'instrutione data ... al S. Giulio Banfi Milanese"" sent by Nini to Kircher.
Ferdinando Giovanni di Gonzaga to Kircher, Castiglione, 27 December 1665
Name of sender added in Kircher's hand"
Ferdinando II de' Medici, Grand Duke of Tuscany, to Kircher, Livorno, 19 March 1666
Ferdinando II de' Medici, Grand Duke of Tuscany

The Grand Duke has been talking with P. Grueber, back via Constantinople, about his travels in China and ""Tartaria"". Grueber claimed to have left travel accounts with Kircher in Rome. 42v=bears the words ""Il Gran Duca"" written twice in Kircher's hand.
Jacopo Nini to Kircher, no place, undated
Nini asks Kircher to examine the enclosed book and inform him of the author.
Jacopo Nini to Kircher, no place, 10 April 1666
"Havendo pèr altro tempo fatta riconoschè la Talia [?]…"" 46v=""Card. Nini"", written in pencil."
Jacopo Nini to Kircher, no place, 21 October 1666
Leopold Wilhelm, Archduke of Austria, to Kircher, Vienna, 3 April 1660

Later published, with minor variants, on the third page of Kircher's Polygraphia Nova (1663). The following is a transcription of the ms letter: ""Devote, syncerè Dilecte; Tametsi iam anteà per tuae Soc[ietatis] Patres complacentiam nostram singularem, quam ex transmissà tuà inventione reciproci cum omnibus populis et Nationibus instituendi Literarum Commercii cepimus, privatim significari fecimus, praetermittere tamen noluimus, quin publicis etiam his nostris Literis eam tibi testatam redderemus. Cuius enim applausum iste vastissimo ingenio tuo dignus et genuinus partus non mereatur? quo Orbis terrarum populos tot Linguarum varietate à se inuicem dissidentes, reddis quasi unilingues, et tam diversarum atque ignotarum Vocum dissonantiam ingeniosissimo communium omnibus notarum invento concordas, naturalemque humanae Linguae imbecillitatem arte mutisque Literis supplere doces. Gratulamur tibi de egregia isthac ingenii tui felicitate, teque hortamur, ut id ipsum ulteriùs excolendo, Lucubrationes tuas posteritatis memoriae consecrare, et per hoc benevolentiam Principum promereri nullatenùs desinas, è quorum numero Nos inprimis te omnigeno Archiducalis n[ost]rae gratiae adfectu complectimur; Dabantur Viennae 3.a Aprilis 1660"". 50v=""Leopoldus Archidux"", in Kircher's hand.
Leopoldo de' Medici to Kircher, Florence, 29 August 1665
Leopoldo compliments Kircher's Arithmologia, which he regards as ""ripiena di concetti ingegnosi et eruditi."" and asks for a copy of the Mundus Subterraneus, which had so pleased Alexander VII.
Friedrich, Landgrave of Hesse-Darmstadt, to Kircher, Heitersheim, 18 September 1665
Friedrich thanks Kircher for sending him a copy of the Arithmologia (""il libro […] de Misterij de numeri"") and says that he will read it with great interest.
Leopoldo de' Medici to Kircher, Florence, 15 September 1665
Leopoldo thanks Kircher for sending a printed folio to be inserted into his work (probably the Arithmologia) 54v=inscription: ""Princip. Leopoldo di Toscana"", in Kircher's hand"
Leopoldo de' Medici to Kircher, Florence, 3 July 1663
Leopoldo thanks Kircher for an unspecified book, most probably the Polygraphia Nova. 56v=inscribed ""Principe Leopoldo di Tosc."", apparently in Kircher's hand.
Friedrich, Landgrave of Hesse-Darmstadt, to Kircher, Heitersheim, 10 August 1663

Compliments an unspecified work of Kircher, ""data in luce sotto l'Augustissimo nome di Sua Maestà Caeserea"", which must be the Polygraphia Nova. Praises Kircher for only allowing himself to be diverted by ""cose curiose e pellegrine"". 58v=address and seal.
Carlo II di Gonzaga Nevers, Duke of Mantua, to Kircher, Mantua, 2 November 1663
Carlo II di Gonzaga Nevers, Duke of Mantua
Thanks Kircher for unspecified work (possibly the Polygraphia Nova). 60v=address and seal.
Leopoldo de' Medici to Kircher, Florence, 17 May 1667

In order that Kircher should not lack works printed in Florence, Leopoldo sends him a work ""in genere d'Anatomia"" published ""presentemente"" by a non-Italian author, currently in Florence. The work in question is almost certainly Niels Stensen's Elementorum myologiae specimen, seu, Musculi descriptio geometrica cui accedunt canis carchariae dissectum caput, et dissectus piscis ex canum genere. - Florentiae : Ex typographia sub signo stellae, 1667. The Danish anatomist Stensen (or Steno or Stenone) was resident in Florence, in the court of Grand Duke Ferdinand II. Leopoldo also discusses the ceremonies in Florence to mark the death of the Queen mother of France. 62v=inscribed ""Princeps Leopoldo"" in Kircher's hand.
Cesare Facchinetti to Kircher, Naples, 19 February 1667

Facchinetti has enriched his library with an unidentified work of Kircher's on obelisks (most probably Obelisci aegyptiaci interpretatio, Rome, 1666). He praises Kircher's work over Bernini's elephant supporting the obelisk of Santa Maria sopra Minerva, pointing out that the latter displays only """"maraviglia"""" whereas Kircher's interpretations display both ""maraviglia"" and ""intelligenza, quella che rende più preziosi I marmi dell'antichità"". 64v=address and seal.
Francesco Maria Brancacci to Kircher, Viterbo, 1 May 1664
"Il P. Dionysio"" gave the Cardinal Kircher's ""Regno Magnetico"" (Magneticum naturae regnum (Rome, 1667)). 66v=address and seal.
Carlo Conti, Duke of Poldi, to Kircher, Poldi, 11 October 1666
Ferdinando II de' Medici, Grand Duke of Tuscany, to Kircher, Florence, 6 July 1663
Ferdinando II de' Medici, Grand Duke of Tuscany
Thanks Kircher for the gift of a work (most probably Polygraphia Nova). 70v=address and seal, with ""Il Gran Principe di Toscana"" written in Kircher's hand
Maximilian Heinrich, Elector of Cologne, to Kircher, Bonn, 29 July 1663
Thanks Kircher for giving a book (probably Polygraphia Nova) to the agent of Henricus Maximilianus in Rome. 72v=address and seal.
Carlo Emanuele II, Duke of Savoy, to Kircher, Turin, 1 August 1663
Carlo Emanuele II, Duke of Savoy
Praises Kircher and thanks him for ""la parte c'hà voluto farmene"", possibly referring to a gift of the Polygraphia Nova. 74v=address and seal.
Joseph Karl, Archduke of Austria, to Kircher, Vienna, 31 December 1661

Inscription in Kircher's hand: ""Hae litterae propria manu Josephi Caroli Archiducis exaratae fuerunt"". The young Archduke thanks Kircher for the gift of his Mathematical Organ, sent to him by way of Fr. Pizzoni. The archduke appreciates the gift of a machine that will allow him to understand the mathematical disciplines easily, and says that the instrument is pleasing him ""magis magisque"".
Kircher to Johann Georg, Prince Elector of Saxony, Rome, 31 October 1665 (draft)
Johann Georg, Prince Elector of Saxony

Kircher sends his recently published Mundus Subterraneus, initiated under the auspices of the late Emperor Ferdinand III, to the Prince Elector of Saxony, both for the splendour of his heroic virtues and ""ob ingentam magna mentis tuae in arcanioris huiusmodi naturae studia propensionem"". 77v= inscription, in Kircher's hand ""Litterae ad Electorem Saxoniae"".
Carlo Conti, Duke of Poldi, to Kircher, Poldi, 12 July 1666
Discusses restoration of the shrine of the Madonna della Mentorella. Historia Eustachio-Mariana. 79v= inscription, in pencil, ""Dux Pili""[?]
Kircher to Ernest, Bishop of Osnabrück, Rome, 30 October 1665 (draft)

Kircher sends a copy of Mundus Subterraneus, ""opera per gli segreti ed arcani della Natura"" to Ernest and his consort, as an expression of his gratitude for the kindness they showed to Kircher during their visit to Rome. The book, Kircher elaborates, was intended to give ""qualche sodisfattione alla lodevole curiosità di Principi virtuosi"".
August, Duke of Braunschweig-Lüneburg to Kircher, Wolfenbüttel, 18/28 June 1666

"Wir zweiffeln nicht, der H. Pater werde unser vorige schreiben erhalten haben, oder theils vor ankunfft dieses noch erhalten, Und alss uns newlicher Tagen von Unserem Bergwercke eub neues gepraege zugekommen welches 5 Reichsthaler an silber in sich heilt, so haben Wir davon eines in goldt verfertigen lassen welches wir dem H. Patri hiermit nebst zwey silbernen zuschicken wollen, obs ihm etwan belieben moechte zur geringen gedaechtnis auffzuheben. Sein Iter Hetruscum werden wir erwarten, sowohl auch des H. Patris // [81v] Olivae primam partem Italicarum Concionum...."".
August, Duke of Braunschweig-Lüneburg to Kircher, Wolfenbüttel, 28 May 1666

"Das Kaestlein mit den Syrischen Evangelistario und kostbaren Oelen und Sassern ist endlich vergangenen Freytag den 25. Hujus St. V. ankommen, und alles woll conditioniret gelifert. Des Herrn Generalis P. Oliva andere Theil seiner Predigten haben Wir auch woll erhalten, moechten den ersten Theil Italiaenisch auch woll haben, vertiret haben wir beyde Theile in Latein vermoege Unseres vorigen schreibens. Wir moechten woll wissen, wessen das Wapen ist, so auff beyde Buecher ausserhalb getrueckt, darinnen lauter Lewen, und unten zwey Hirschgeweihe. Die sehr woll riechende quarti und die 3 ventil gefallen Unserer Consortae sehr woll. Der Truecker zu Amsterdam wird das Iter Hetruscum vielleicht noch nicht fertig haben, sonsten thun Wir uns bedancken, wegen Ueberlassung des so raren siebenhundert Jaehrigen Syrischen Exemplars, und soll uns sonderlich lieb seyn, weiln es von dem Hern Patre hergekommen, haben es gelich unter Unsere Msta. Auff. Der Bibliotheck setzen lassen. Wir haben Unsern Johann Georg Ankeln befohlen, cito euch 400 Rthl.per wechweìsel zu uebermachen wormit ihr vor die mahl wollet vorlieb nehmen"". The letter discusses August's gift of 400 Reichsthaler to Kircher, also mentioned in Kircher's Vita (1684), but placed in the year 1661. 83v= inscription (in Kircher's hand?) """"Augustus 400 scu[di]""""."" Fletcher, Athanasius Kircher und, p. 133.
August, Duke of Braunschweig-Lüneburg to Kircher, Wolfenbüttel, 7/17 August 1665

Thanks K. for medicines and ""chemical things"" from pharmacy, but adds ""that the correct dosage should be written on them, and also which sickness they are for"" August has ""seine drey schreiben vom 21. Febr: 8. Maii und 25 Julii woll erhalten"", points out however ""dass darin angedeutete Buch aber, nemblich die Historia Eustachio Marianam ist Uns nicht geliefert"". [f. 84v] ""Sonsten ist Uns lieb, dass ihm das geringe geldt geliefert, Er wird also darmit vor diesmahl vorlieb nehmen, und bedarff dasselbe einer so grossen dancksagung gar nichtm es ist nur zu einer geringen anzeige Unserer bestendigen zu ihm tragenden affection. Das Iter Hetruscum wird woll zulesen seyn, wan der Gran Duca la Republica di Luca auch hette, welches aber der Pabst und Der Kaiser als ihre Patroni nicht zugeben werden, koente er sich Regem Hetruria schreiben, // [f. 85r] dass der H.P. ihm gefallen lassen, obgemeltes Iter Hetruscum Uns zu dediciren, daraus verspueren Wir seine gute bestendige affection, die Wir jederzeit vermercket werden es dancknehmig zuerkennen wissen. Wirverspueren auch dieselbe noch weiter daraus, dass er Uns von Chymischen sachen aus ihrer Apotheck mittheilen wolle, es werden Uns dieselbe sehr angenehm seyn, und sehgen gerne, dass der Dosis allezeit dabey geschreiben werden moechte, und gegen was fuer Kranckheiten dieselbe nuetzlich zugebrauchen, dan wan man den Dosin nicht recht wuesste, man leichtlich an statt des nutzes schaden daran erfahren wuerde. Wie fueglich alles auf Augsspurg verschaffen, wird ihm Unser Anckel an die Handt gebenm sofern es nicht albereit von ihm geschehen. Was der Josephus Campanus vom [symbol for Saturn] und [symbol for Jupiter] herauss geben, ist woll zumercken, der Tubus hat uns viel entdecket, so den Alten unbewust gewesen, wegen mangel des scharffen gesichtes. Der Galilaeus in Florentz hat de Confectione Tuborum insonderheit seine gedancken heraus gegeben. // [f. 85v] Was der H. Pater de abditis numerorum mysteriis geschreiben, wollen wir angedeuteter massen von ihm erwarten. Es hat vor 51 Jahren Petrus Bungus Bergomas auch einer Tractat de mumerorum mysteriis ausgehen lassen, so in Unserer Bibliotheck verhanden, ist getrucket zu Bergamo Anno 1614 in 4to und lautet dessen Titul also: Petri Bungi Bergomatis Numerorum mysteria ex abditis plurimarum disciplinarum fontibus hausta. Dass wegen der Succession in die verlassene Fuerstenthuember Unsers newlich denati Agnati Christiani Ludovici, streitt zwischen den Herrn Gebruedern Georgio Wilhelmio und Johanne Friderico entstanden, wird ohnezweiffel Fama auch ueber die Alpes gebracht haben, und zwar so heftig, dass uterque militem conscriberet gehabt, es ist aber Gott sey danck derselbe ex fundamentis cum utiusque hoc contento numehr beygeleget, welche bona nova Wir dem H. Pat: auch mittheilen wollen, es heisset ja billig, Pacem te possimus Omnes. Es hat viele muehe gekostet, dieses glimmende feuer zudempffen, und die Laender und Fuerstenthuember in frieden zuerhalten"". Draft at HAB: BA No. 369/2.
August, Duke of Braunschweig-Lüneburg to Kircher, Wolfenbüttel, 21/31 January 1666

"Wir haben seine angenaeme drey schreiben, vom 1, und 22. Aug. Dell'Anno passato, und 8. Jan 1666 aus Rom, ueber Venedig, Augsburg und Nuroberg wol erhalten. Es hatte der H. Pater es nicht noetig gehabt, eine so hohe Dancksagung wegen der uebermachten quadrini, zu ueberscreiben. Er wolle nuhr mit denselben fuer dyses mahl verlyb naemen. Was er uns sonsten an Buechern, und einen Ms uebersenden wird, solches sol uns lyb und gantz angenaem kommen. Wir schikken Ihm hierbey eine Reformatione Calendarii eines Nuernbergischen professoris zu Altdorff [i.e. Abdias Trew, Gruendliche Kalender Kunst in zwei Theil verfasst, Lueneburg, 1666] und moechten wol des H. patris Judicium, wan Er so weit a magis feriis abmuessigen koente, darueber vernaemen wy man astronomice ex politice der lang begehrten, und vielmaal tartirten, wiewol // [f.86v] bishero undurno Enderung schaffen moechte"". 87v=inscription (in Kircher's hand?): ""Augustus dux gratias agit de transmissis medicamentis et extenuat munus subsidiarium transmissum"". Draft at HAB: BA No. 369/1.
August, Duke of Braunschweig-Lüneburg to Kircher, Wolfenbüttel, 16/26 April 1666
General of the Society of Jesus

August wishes to obtain G.P. Oliva's books for his library. 88r: He has received Kircher's letter of 19 March and 2 April ""worinnen auch zugleich des Herrn P. Generalis Johan: Pauli Olivae S.J. Tomus 2. Concionum Apostolicarum italico idiomate conscriptarum geleget. Die lateinische version Tomi prioris et posterioris desselben Concionum, selche der Johan: de Bussiers quisdem S. in lateinischer sprache heraus gegeben, haben wir in Unserer Bibliothek. Primum librum earundem concionum in Italianischer // [f. 88v] sprache moechten Wir umb die gebuerm zu completierung derselben, auch woll haben, umb Uns damit in der Italiaenischen sprache zuueben, so wir in annis 89. 90 und 600 in Jubliaeo, tempore P. M. Clementis 8vi. P.m. in etwas gefasset"".
Leopoldo de' Medici to Kircher, Florence, 10 July 1666

Thanks Kircher for sending him the ""libretto dell'interpretazione dell'Obelisco Egiziaco"", i.e. Obelisci aegyptiaci interpretatio (Rome, 1666), and praises Niels Stensen (Stenone). 90v=inscription in pencil: ""Principe Leopoldo di Toscana"".
Johann Friedrich, Duke of Braunschweig-Lüneburg to Kircher, Hannover, 3 December 1665
Mentions that Johann Friedrich is expecting a book from Kircher and has already received his letter. 92v=address and seal, with (in pencil) ""Dux Luneburg"".
Friedrich, Landgrave of Hesse-Darmstadt to Kircher, Heitersheim, 8 February 1666
Refers to letter from Kircher of 26 December 1665.
Maximilian Heinrich, Elector of Cologne, to Kircher, Bonn, 13 December 1663
Thanks Kircher for three works: Mundus Subterraneus, Historia Eustachio-Mariana and Arithmologia. 95v=address and seal, with ""Elector Colon."" written in a different hand in pencil.
Leopoldo de' Medici to Kircher, Florence, 3 August 1666

Thanks Kircher for his Obelisci aegyptiaci interpretatio (Rome, 1666). Writing ""Non prima ho dichiarata a V[ostra] R[everenza] la propria gratitudine per il Dono del libro che mi ha mandato dell'Interpretazione fatto da Lei all'Obelisco Egizio, recentemente ritrovato negli Orti della Minerva, perche volsi avanti scorrerlo…"". 97v=address and seal, with ""Gran Principe"" inscribed in pen (possibly in Kircher's hand) and in pencil (unknown hand).
Kircher to Joseph Karl, Archduke of Austria, Rome, 7 July 1661 (draft)

Kircher is sending his mathematical organ to the Archduke by way of Fr. Pizzoni. The organ was later described in Gaspar Schott, Organum Mathematicum Libris IX. Explicatum, Herbipoli, 1668. Inc. ""Mitto per manus P. Pizzoni Serenissimae Vestrae Celsitudini, Instrumentum quoddam quod Organum mathematicum appello; in quo summa facilitate traduntur illae Artes mathematicae, ad quas Serentitatem vestram inclinari audio, Regibus et Principibus uti par est, nullo non tempore summo in honore habitae…"". 98v=inscription (in Kircher's hand): ""Litterae ad Joseph. Carl. Archiduc."
Johann Georg, Prince Elector of Saxony, to Kircher, Dresden, January 1666
Johann Georg, Prince Elector of Saxony
Johann Georg thanks Kircher for the gift of the Mundus Subterraneus. 100v=address and seal with, in Kircher's hand ""Electoris Saxoniae gratias agit pro transmisso Mundo subterraneo"
Johann Georg, Prince Elector of Saxony, to Kircher, Dresden, 11 December 1663
Johann Georg, Prince Elector of Saxony
Kircher to Alexander VII, Pope (Fabio Chigi), no place, undated (draft)

Kircher asks the Pope for permission to be granted for Elizabeth of Palatine, wife of the Duke of Luneburg, to be granted permission to visit the Collegio Romano, including its library and Kircher's Museum as well as the Domus Professa, arguing that although the princess is not of the Catholic she is ""ab ea tamen non aliena"", and ""virorum literatorum praesertim Soc. nostrae, quibuscum iam dudum in Germania assueverat, commercium ambit"". Kircher notes that the power to grant such permission is reserved to the Pope alone: ""respondi eiusmodi facultatem neque me, neque P. Generalem, neque quenquam alium concedete posse, utpote soli Summo Pontifici, cui iure religionis omnes subdimur, reservatam"". 102v=in Kircher's hand ""Ad Alex. VII P.M. pro Palatina"".
Kircher to the Holy Roman Emperor [Leopold I?], no place, undated (draft)
Kircher sends the Emperor an image of St. Athanasius made of feathers which he has received from a Priest returning from Mexico.
Ferdinand Maria, Elector of Bavaria, to Kircher, Munich, 19 October 1663
Thanks Kircher for Polygraphia Nova. 105v=address and seal.
Francesco Maria Brancacci to Kircher, Viterbo, 18 March 1665
Thanks Kircher for sending Gioseffo Petrucci [Athanasius Kircher], Fisiologia Nuova della Natura delle Comete (Rome, 1665). Discusses astronomical observations. 107v=address and seal.
Fisiologia Nuova della Natura delle Comete
Leopoldo de' Medici to Kircher, Florence, 13 October 1666

Leopoldo sends Kircher a copy of a new book by ""Dottor Chimentelli"", presumably Valerio Chimentelli, Marmor Pisanum de honore bisellii. Parergon inseritur de veterum sellis ... Accedit Myiodia, sive de muscis odoris Pisanis epistola. Ex typographia haeredis V. Benatii: Bononiae, 1666. 109v=inscription, in Kircher's hand (?) ""Principe Leopoldo."
Kircher to Ferdinand Maria, Elector of Bavaria, Rome, 12 July 1666 (draft)
Kircher sends the Duke a copy of his Obelisci aegyptiaci interpretatio (Rome, 1666) 100v=inscription in Kircher's hand: ""Litterae ad Ducem Bavariae"".
Ferdinand Johann, Prince of Lichtenstein to Kircher, Vienna, 14 June 1665
Acknowledges receipt of letter from Kircher of 23 May 1665, ""cum inclusis"". 112v=address and seal.
Kircher to August, Duke of Braunschweig-Lüneburg, no place, undated [Rome, 19 March 1666] (draft)
General of the Society of Jesus

Kircher forwards to August a manuscript of the four gospels in Estranghelo-Syriac, written in the form of Syriac used in Palestine at the time of Christ. 114v=inscribed in Kircher's hand ""Serm. Augusto Duc. Brun."" Kircher also forwards to August the work of G.P. Oliva (General of the Society of Jesus) Conciones Apostolicarum, and ""olea pretiosa et aquae odoriferae separatis arculis inclusae: servientque tum ad spiritus contentione studiorum exhaustos instaurandos"". The copy of the letter actually sent to August (dated 19 March 1666) is in HAB 6 Novissimi 2o ff. 59-61
Kircher to Ferdinando II de' Medici, Grand Duke of Tuscany, no place, undated (draft)
Ferdinando II de' Medici, Grand Duke of Tuscany

Aut.re del med.mo Veram.te il Nome Kirchero essaltato e lodato dà più d'una lingua, era dovere, che finalm.te comparisse ancora in forma di lingue p[er] informare con artificiosa Poligrafia la Nobilità Peregrina, et I Prencipi Curiosi"". 117v=address and seal, with (in a different hand) ""Don Federico, Duca di Brunswick."

""L'intendimento cosi perfetto che V. P. possiede di tante scienze et il diletto che ella ritrova in rimirare l'altruj virtuose fatiche mi persuadono giustamente adesso ad inviarlene alcune date presentamente alla luce dal Nostro Matematico Dottor Borelli sopra le Cause fisiche de moti, et apparenze dei Pianetini di Giove. Et parendomi di riconoscere in questa Operetta speculazioni cosi curiose, et stimabili, non ho dubbio che la Paternità Vostra sia per cortesemente gradirla"". 127v=""Leopoldo Principe di Toscana"" (in Kircher's hand?).

The Duke has received Kircher's letter from Fr. Francesco Mazzarota. He asks for the two volumes of Kircher's Mundus Subterraneus, which he will repay with two volumes that he is printing at the moment. Also asks Kircher for advice on translating the Greek names of two birds, Erithouro and Drioclaptos, and information on how best to represent them in copper-engraving.

Thanks Kircher for his letter of 20 June 1665. Nadasdy received the Mundus subterraneus in Belgium, and praises it highly. He approves of Kircher's plan to dedicate the 1665 Arithmologia (""Librum de numerorum mysterijs"") to him, but cannot yet provide Kircher with a suitable engraved portrait for the title-page, for lack of a painter. 148v=address, seal, drawings in pencil and ""Nadasti"" in different hand/ink.

Christian August (not Christiaan Huygens, as earlier inventories of the correspondence suggest), who had visited Kircher in Rome earlier in the year, describes the island, and provides Kircher with news about German dignitaries. ""Questa Isola nutrisce 2 compagnie delle truppe regie, et è fatigata giornalmente per le continue contributioni. Se dice ch'il Conte Ulfeld sarà liberato dalla sua prigione, la cio certezza sapremo subito. M'ora proposto d'andar alla corte, ma aspettaro fin ch'habbia risposta sopra alcune lettere // [151v] ivi mandate. E mentre non ho niente da fare passo il mio tempo con ricogliere nella memoria e perleggere i suoi libri"". Thanks Kircher for his ""fatighe et amabili instruttioni"", and adds that ""Il Sig. Holsten si bacia le mani. Riverisco Il P[ad]re Montesio"""". 152v=address and seal.
Francesco Pianezza to Kircher, Turin, 19 July 1663

Thanks Kircher for letter, and gift of ""il suo pregiato volume"", possibly the Polygraphia Nova. The Marchese adds that ""con grand[issi]mo gusto mi son trattenuto molto tempo nel legger li suoi scritti publicati al mondo della luce de magnetismi della musica et della sapienza egittiana"". He impatiently awaits the Mundus Subterraneus"". 169v=""Marchese Pianezza"" (in Kircher's hand).
Francisco Ximénez (François Giliot) to Kircher, Puebla de los Angeles, 1 April 1655

Ximinez introduces himself as ""ille quam R.a V.a Lugduni amicorum suorum catalogo inscripsu Franciscus Gilotius"", demonstrating that he met Kircher in Lyon. He has leafed through Kircher's Magnes, but has not yet had a chance to read the Prodromus Coptus. He also sends Kircher chocolate and images made from feathers, 155v=address and seal.
Juan Caramuel Lobkowic to Kircher, Naples, 24 March 1665

Discussion, with diagram, of the issue of whether the comet of 1664 was above or below the sun, based on considerations of parallax. Caramuel, who judges that the comet was below the sun, has received Kircher's work on the comet ( Gioseffo Petrucci [Athanasius Kircher], Fisiologia Nuova della Natura delle Comete (Rome, 1665)). He has also received a table of the motion of the comet according to Meyer. 157v= ""D. Caramuel de Concu."" in different hand.
Fisiologia Nuova della Natura delle Comete
Juan Caramuel Lobkowic to Kircher, Naples, 27 October 1662

Caramuel has received an unidentified book from Kircher, and previously written to him by way of the Duke of Diano. He asks for Kircher to send observations of the recent lunar eclipse, made both in Bologna and Rome. Caramuel wishes to publish his Cursus Mathematicus, but is detained by the lack of an engraver.
Juan Caramuel Lobkowic to Kircher, Naples, 14 January 1665

Caramuel thanks Kircher for sending cometary observations made in the month of December, and requests those made in January. He is astonished by the speed of the comet. He also asks Kircher when the Mundus Subterraneus will appear.

Ferdinando Giovanni di Gonzaga to Kircher, Castiglione. 26 May 1661

Ferdinando has received from Kircher letters and his ""libretto sopra l'apparitione delle Croci in Napoli"" which he finds ""pieno di sing.le dottrina, e di curios.me osservatione"". 288v=address and seal.
Leopold I, Holy Roman Emperor, to Kircher,Vienna 22 June 1667
Kircher to Alexander VII, Pope (Fabio Chigi), Rome, 27 April 1660 (draft)

Kircher has sent a manuscript to Alexander VII (""in hac de Numerorum origine [Diatriba]…""). This is presumably a reference to the short manuscript treatise ""De Origine eorum numerorum, quos Zyphras vulgo vocant, quibus hoc tempore in computu rerum omnes uti solent"", BAV Chigi J.VI.225, ff. 78r-80v. 8v= note in Kircher's hand.
Ferdinand III, Holy Roman Emperor, to Kircher, Regensburg, 24 April 1654
Ferdinando Giovanni di Gonzaga to Kircher, Castiglione, 12 July 1663

Praises the Polygraphia Nova ("" … la nuova opera hà dato alle stampe, coll'insegnam.to di corrispondersi, per lettere, con tutte le Nationi del Mondo …""). Also mentions the ""medaglione"" he is having made. 168v=address and seal

Apollonius of Perga, Conics, beginning of Book V (in Arabic)

This text has been identified by Jan Hogendijk, of the University of Utrecht, who suggests that it is the revision of al-Isfahani or al-Shirazi brought to Europe from Constantinople by Christianus Ravius and exhibited to various scholars in Holland between 1642 and 1647 . Only books I to IV of the Conics survived in Greek, and were first translated in an edition by Giovanni-Battista Memmo at Venice in 1537. This edition, which contained many errors, was replaced by Federico Commandino's translation, published in Bologna in 1566. Various versions of books V-VII in Arabic circulated in Europe during the seventeenth century. In 1629, Jacobus Golius brought a Codex of the Conics to Leiden, and planned to publish a translation of the lost books. In the 1640s the English mathematician John Pell worked on a translation of another manuscript of the Conics, brought back from Constantinople by Christian Ravius. Information from Apollonius Conics Books V to VII: The Arabic Translation of the Lost Greek Original in the Version of the Banu Musa, edited with translation and commentary by G.J. Toomer, New York: Springer-Verlag, 1990, vol. 1, xx-xxv, and Fuat Sezgin, Geschichte des Arabischen Schrifttums, Leiden: Brill, 1974, Band V, p. 141
